source:
Theorem 3.4.14 (Principle of Inclusion Exclusion for 3 Sets)
Given three sets, |A1|,|A2|,|A3|,
|A1∪A2∪A3|=|A1|+|A2|+|A3|−|A1∩A2|−|A1∩A3|−|A2∩A3|+|A1∩A2∩A3|
question: If \( |A_1| = 4 \), \( |A_2| = 5 \), \( |A_3| = 6 \), \( |A_1 \cap A_2| = 1 \), \( |A_1 \cap A_3| = 2 \), \( |A_2 \cap A_3| = 3 \), and \( |A_1 \cap A_2 \cap A_3| = 1 \), what is \( |A_1 \cup A_2 \cup A_3| \)?
solution:
Using the principle of inclusion-exclusion for three sets:

\[
|A_1 \cup A_2 \cup A_3| = |A_1| + |A_2| + |A_3| - |A_1 \cap A_2| - |A_1 \cap A_3| - |A_2 \cap A_3| + |A_1 \cap A_2 \cap A_3|
\]

Substituting the values:

\[
|A_1 \cup A_2 \cup A_3| = 4 + 5 + 6 - 1 - 2 - 3 + 1 = 10
\]

Thus, the number of elements in the union is \( \boxed{10} \).
